ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Martin, The CPPNs we used have a distance from center output. So they are easily able to make spheres in the center of the bounding box (by just using that

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hi Martin,

The CPPNs we used have a distance from center output. So they a=
re easily able to make spheres in the center of the bounding box (by just u=
sing that input and ignoring x, y, and z). We often saw spherical "rollers"=
 that dropped and expanded part of their sphere to push them away from the =
origin. So there is nothing in principle that prevented them from elaborati=
ng on a symmetrical, spherical starting point.  


Best regards,
Jeff Clune=


Assistant Professor
Computer Science
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@uwyo=
.edu
jeffclune.com

On Apr 15, 2013, at 6:21 AM, martin_pyka <martin.pyka@g=
mail.com> wrote:

> > > That certainly makes sense. It raises the question =
of how bilateral symmetry arose in biological organisms.
> 
> I have no lin=
k to literature or any kind of evidence, but with regard to this paper I wa=
s wondering what kind of creatures would emerge if you would start with an =
organism that has spherical symmetry (as far as you can represent spherical=
 symmetry with voxels ;)) encoded through a CPPN. This ancestor organism wo=
uld be something like a unicellular organism in nature. Starting with a CPP=
N of such an organism would mean that radial and bilateral symmetry is in a=
ctual fact a departure from spherical symmetry. And I suspect that from thi=
s starting position bilateral symmetry should be easier to reach (and it is=
 maybe biologically more plausible!?).
> 
> @Jeff: can you try that for us?=
 :-)
> 
> From this perspective, complexification (or diversification) woul=
d mean breaking the symmetry rather than approaching it, which seems to me =
more natural. But as I said, I am not familiar with the literature in this =
area.
> 
> Best,
> Martin
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_FCA5EEAE-7C1C-434E-808A-3CF960287832

<div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>> > That certainly makes sense. It raises th=
e question of how bilateral symmetry arose in biological organisms.<br>
<br=
>
I have no link to literature or any kind of evidence, but with regard to =
this paper I was wondering what kind of creatures would emerge if you would=
 start with an organism that has spherical symmetry (as far as you can repr=
esent spherical symmetry with voxels ;)) encoded through a CPPN. This ances=
tor organism would be something like a unicellular organism in nature. Star=
ting with a CPPN of such an organism would mean that radial and bilateral s=
ymmetry is in actual fact a departure from spherical symmetry. And I suspec=
t that from this starting position bilateral symmetry should be easier to r=
each (and it is maybe biologically more plausible!?).<br>
<br>
@Jeff: can y=
ou try that for us? :-)<br>
<br>
From this perspective, complexification (o=
r diversification) would mean breaking the symmetry  rather than approachin=
g it, which seems to me more natural. But as I said, I am not familiar with=
 the literature in this area.<br>
<br>
Best,<br>
Martin<br>
<br>
</p>

    =
